awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

One of the biggest changes in economics in the 21st century is the increasing availability of comprehensive, high quality, micro-level data on households and firms. To utilize all this data meaningfully, we need macroeconomic models with enough flexibility to be able to leverage and organize all this information. However, such models can be so complex that they turn into unworkable black boxes, whereby it becomes difficult to know where the results are coming from, and how sensitively they depend on the assumptions. This project develops data-driven theory which aggregates granular data by combining the flexibility of computational models with the transparency of theoretical ones.  The project then applies these theories to newly-available micro datasets to investigate important macroeconomic issues such as productivity, economic growth, trade and inequality.
  
This project will develop and apply new aggregation results for economies with non-neoclassical production like fixed costs, increasing returns to scale, entry-exit margins, and discontinuities. These are issues that are typically abstracted away from in both the measurement and analysis of national income and growth. This project will extend classical aggregation theorems that allow for non-linearities, distortions, heterogeneous agents, heterogeneous firms, production networks, and international trade further to environments with non-neoclassical, non-convex, and non-continuous production structures. The project will apply the theoretical results to recently available micro-level datasets that can discipline and put structure on the rich range of theoretical possibilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The award funded research on aggregation in macroeconomics. The funding helped in the writing of 19 papers, 10 of which have been published in academic journals so far. The papers covered a diverse range of topics including: how the Covid-19 pandemic shut downs affected the US economy, how to decompose the Covid-19 crisis into supply and demand shocks and how those shocks interacted with government policies, how changes in consumer preferences affect real GDP and economic welfare, how increases in market size affect allocational efficiency in economies with monopolistic competition and firm entry, how imperfect competition and pass-through of marginal cost into prices affect the transmission of monetary policy into aggregate productivity, how tariffs and trade barriers affect welfare and output in global production networks, how to measure cost-of-living indices over time, how a Russian gas stop would affect the German economy, how to measure consumer welfare in a way that accounts for beliefs about the future, how the formation and destruction of firm-to-firm supply relationships affect growth and productivity, and how capital accumulation affects output in models with heterogeneous producers and firms. The unifying theme in this research has been aggregation of high-dimensional heterogeneity into interpretable low-dimensional numbers. This resulted in research on fundamental theory as well as applications to specific real world concerns. For example, the award funded research relevant for understanding how Covid-19 affected the economy, how trade wars affect consumers and workers, and how gas sanctions on Russia would affect the German economy.
